thread.title: Holmes à Court remains Northern Territory's largest individual pastoral land owner
thread.title_full: Holmes à Court remains Northern Territory's largest individual pastoral land owner

author: Carl Curtain
title: Holmes à Court remains Northern Territory's largest individual pastoral land owner
text:
Map: Katherine 0850 
Australian businessman Paul Holmes à Court remains the largest individual owner of pastoral land in the Northern Territory, with over 16,700 square kilometres. 
The Heytesbury Cattle Company, solely-owned by Mr Holmes à Court since 2008, holds four pastoral leases in the NT, including well known cattle station Victoria River Downs, south west of Katherine. 
Heytesbury further expanded its operations last year by buying Humbert River Station , to add to the other leases Wallamunga and Birrindudu. 
The recent arrival of Gina Rinehart to the Top End, who has acquired several properties, has not gone unnoticed by the local industry but the mining magnate will need to spend more if she's to become the "single largest" owner of land in the NT, as some have purported. 
In 2016, Ms Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting purchased Inverway and Riveren pastoral leases, and Helen Springs, Brunchilly and Banka Banka East via a joint venture with Shanghai CRED , known as Australian Outback Beef. 
Hancock Prospecting also bought Phoenix Park , a smaller free-hold block near Katherine, used as a cattle processing depot. 
But the collective area of her newly acquired assets is still short of Mr Holmes à Court, even with the shared Shanghai CRED interests. 
The two pastoral leases in the Victoria River District and three on the Barkly Tableland, total just over 16,000 square kilometres. 
While there has long been interest in the ownership of land in the north, any new comers - foreign or domestic - have been welcomed by the cattle industry . 
Renowned Territory cattleman Ian McBean, who came to the north in 1952 and went on to own several stations, said the local beef sector had been developed for decades with the support of both Australian and overseas-based investors. 
"You need that capital to come in to better your infrastructure, better your genetics and increase the productivity of the area," he said. 
Mr McBean said the ownership of properties should be irrelevant provided they were managed well. 
"I suppose my fear of any big corporate or overseas-owned property is the quality of management, the knowledge of management," he said. 
"I consider that actual experience, on the ground working stock, is still very important. 
"But by the same token I don't knock the financial knowledge, and also the knowledge of different grasses and the genetics that are coming into the industry now." 
The major pastoral companies, which have a number of shareholders as opposed to being controlled by an individual, have significantly more land in their respective portfolios. 
Australian Agricultural Company holds 39,100 square kilometres, Consolidated Pastoral Company has 31,700 square kilometres and North Australian Pastoral Company owns 21,900 square kilometres. 
Mr McBean said the size of a property was not generally a good indication of value, but rather the stock carrying capacity of the land. 
"That's where your productivity comes from - from the number of calves you can get on the ground," he said. 
"You can have the biggest place in the world, but if it's got a low carrying capacity, you're not going to get the financial return that you're going to get out of a smaller place that can carry more cattle."
